Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Variable Geometry Dies for Polymer Extrusion

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant provides funding to develop variable-geometry dies for extruding complex plastic parts. Unlike most existing polymer extrusion dies, which have a single fixed geometry, design techniques will be created to build novel moving dies that morph between different shapes. Coordination of multiple actuators during the extrusion process will impose these changes in shape. The actuator locations will be optimized to provide the mechanical advantage required to resist the sizable pressure loads inside the extruder. The optimization will be accomplished with a genetic algorithm that considers the many design constraints, which include avoiding interference of moving parts, eliminating obstructions to the flow of the molten plastic, achieving a reasonably sized die, and minimizing actuator power consumption. Experimental work will develop new ways to manage the leakage of molten plastic within the die due to its moving parts. Prototype variable-geometry dies will be built and tested on a production extruder operated by an industrial collaborator. Validation experiments will derive empirical relationships between changes in the die geometry, extruder screw speed, and plastic temperature to provide process control settings that yield defect-free parts.

This research seeks to create the next generation of polymer extrusion dies that can produce a wider variety of more complex plastic parts. Specifically, the work aims to enable polymer extrusion to replace injection molding for a class of plastic parts, thereby simultaneously reducing production costs and manufacturing time. Additionally, it aspires to offer designers the flexibility to create novel engineering solutions with entirely new plastic parts of varying cross sectional shape. The developed design tools will have broader application to creating other variable-geometry structures such as morphing aircraft wings and micro-scale extrusion dies.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Extrusion is a process in which polymer pellets are melted and pushed by a rotating screw through a die. Extrusion is popular in a wide range of applications including the manufacture of pipes, household siding, decorative molding, drinking straws, gutter systems, weather stripping, and window framing components. Because this process happens continuously, extrusion benefits from speeds and costs superior to other polymer processing technologies. The extrusion die’s function is to shape the molten polymer into the desired cross section. Conventional extrusion uses a stationary die in the continuous manufacture of plastic products and is therefore limited to making parts of constant cross-section. Prior to this research, the extrusion process did not have the flexibility to accommodate a wider range of more complex products due to the limitations of stationary die design.

This research introduced an entirely new class of dies called variable polymer extrusion dies. These new dies include moving parts that change the orifice cross-section as the molten polymer flows through. As such, these dies are capable of producing plastic parts of greater complexity than any currently extruded via conventional technology while maintaining comparable repeatability. The high speeds and low costs compared to other polymer processing technologies makes this new class of dies economically desirable. Key advances of this research include various design options for including the moving parts inside the die that allow the molten plastic to flow through it while limiting the flow into those moving parts.

This research also established methods for the systematic development of variable-geometry extrusion dies driven by the desired shape-change in the final part’s cross section. This systematic development includes a new set of methodologies and computational tools that have been experimentally validated to demonstrate the industrial viability of variable-geometry extrusion dies. As such, this project has the potential to enhance the competitiveness of U.S. manufacturers who do polymer extrusion.

Beyond die design, this work could lead to advances in machine design in other applications through its significant extensions to shape-changing rigid-body mechanism theory. Applications include aircraft wings, vehicle spoilers, and orthotics and prosthetics. This research has also produced a new method to perform morphometry, the quantitative comparison of shapes.

This project occurred as part of a collaboration with PI James Schmiedeler of the University of Notre Dame (NSF award no. 1234383). The collaboration resulted in a variety of advances in shape-changing mechanism theory and variable-geometry die design from fundamental theory, through mechanical design, prototyping and testing, and into the control of the die’s actuators for improved extruded part accuracy. All experimentation and production runs were completed in conjunction with Creative Extruded Products of Tipp City, Ohio.

At the University of Dayton, the project involved 25 students via semester long class projects, summer research opportunities, assisting in on-site experimentation with prototypes, or performing the basic research. Of the 25, 13 received funding under the grant itself or REU supplements, and 7 of the participants were women. This research also generated a variety of projects and motivating examples, including hardware for students to interact with, throughout the University of Dayton’s mechanical systems classes which range from first-year into graduate level coursework. Finally, this work now appears in a variety of outreach programs.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Extrusion is a process in which polymer pellets are melted and pushed by a rotating screw through a die. Extrusion is popular in a wide range of applications including the manufacture of pipes, household siding, decorative molding, drinking straws, gutter systems, weather stripping, and window framing components. Because this process happens continuously, extrusion benefits from speeds and costs superior to other polymer processing technologies. The extrusion die?s function is to shape the molten polymer into the desired cross section. Conventional extrusion uses a stationary die in the continuous manufacture of plastic products and is therefore limited to making parts of constant cross-section. Prior to this research, the extrusion process did not have the flexibility to accommodate a wider range of more complex products due to the limitations of stationary die design. This research introduced an entirely new class of dies called variable polymer extrusion dies. These new dies include moving parts that change the orifice cross-section as the molten polymer flows through. As such, these dies are capable of producing plastic parts of greater complexity than any currently extruded via conventional technology while maintaining comparable repeatability. The high speeds and low costs compared to other polymer processing technologies makes this new class of dies economically desirable. Key advances of this research include various design options for including the moving parts inside the die that allow the molten plastic to flow through it while limiting the flow into those moving parts. This research also established methods for the systematic development of variable-geometry extrusion dies driven by the desired shape-change in the final part?s cross section. This systematic development includes a new set of methodologies and computational tools that have been experimentally validated to demonstrate the industrial viability of variable-geometry extrusion dies. As such, this project has the potential to enhance the competitiveness of U.S. manufacturers who do polymer extrusion. Beyond die design, this work could lead to advances in machine design in other applications through its significant extensions to shape-changing rigid-body mechanism theory. Applications include aircraft wings, vehicle spoilers, and orthotics and prosthetics. This research has also produced a new method to perform morphometry, the quantitative comparison of shapes. This project occurred as part of a collaboration with PI James Schmiedeler of the University of Notre Dame (NSF award no. 1234383). The collaboration resulted in a variety of advances in shape-changing mechanism theory and variable-geometry die design from fundamental theory, through mechanical design, prototyping and testing, and into the control of the die?s actuators for improved extruded part accuracy. All experimentation and production runs were completed in conjunction with Creative Extruded Products of Tipp City, Ohio. At the University of Dayton, the project involved 25 students via semester long class projects, summer research opportunities, assisting in on-site experimentation with prototypes, or performing the basic research. Of the 25, 13 received funding under the grant itself or REU supplements, and 7 of the participants were women. This research also generated a variety of projects and motivating examples, including hardware for students to interact with, throughout the University of Dayton?s mechanical systems classes which range from first-year into graduate level coursework.
